chunks.title: Section 351 IPC - Assault
chunks.content: Whoever makes any gesture or preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture or preparation will cause any person present to apprehend that he is about to use criminal force, is said to commit an assault.
chunks.summary: Defines assault as gesture or act causing apprehension of force.

chunks.title: Section 352 IPC - Punishment for Assault
chunks.content: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation, shall be punished with imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
chunks.summary: Punishment for assault without grave provocation.

chunks.title: Nature of Offence
chunks.content: Section 351/352 IPC offences are cognizable; police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.
chunks.summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.

chunks.title: Bailability
chunks.content: Section 351/352 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

chunks.title: Trial Jurisdiction
chunks.content: Section 351/352 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session due to seriousness.

chunks.title: Witness Testimony
chunks.content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt in assault cases.
chunks.summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.

chunks.title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
chunks.content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause, or identity of accused in assault cases.
chunks.summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.

chunks.title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
chunks.content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) to establish liability for assault.
chunks.summary: Both mental and physical elements required.

chunks.case_name: Rupan Deol Bajaj v. KPS Gill
chunks.ratio: Assault established by act causing apprehension.
Grave provocation can reduce punishment for assault.

chunks.question: What is the punishment under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Punishment includes imprisonment and/or fine as provided by law.

chunks.question: Is Section 351/352 a bailable offence?
chunks.answer: No, it is generally non-bailable.

chunks.question: Is Section 351/352 a cognizable offence?
chunks.answer: Yes, police may register FIR and investigate without magistrate approval.

chunks.question: What is the legal definition of assault under Section 351 IPC?
chunks.answer: Assault is any gesture or preparation to use criminal force, intentionally causing apprehension of harm in another person.

chunks.question: What is criminal force under Section 352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Criminal force is using force intentionally without consent in order to commit an offence or cause injury, fear, or annoyance.

chunks.question: Is assault under Section 351/352 IPC compoundable?
chunks.answer: Yes, assault and use of criminal force under Sections 351/352 are typically compoundable with court permission.

chunks.question: Which court tries offences under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Usually tried by Magistrate courts as these are less serious offences.

chunks.question: Can assault under Section 351 IPC occur without any physical contact?
chunks.answer: Yes, assault involves an act or gesture causing apprehension of harmâ€”even without physical contact.

chunks.question: Is intention necessary for conviction under Section 352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, intention to use force is a necessary ingredient for conviction.

chunks.question: What is the maximum punishment for assault under Section 352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Maximum punishment is imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to 500 rupees, or both.

chunks.question: Can minors be prosecuted under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, but juvenile offenders are dealt with under the Juvenile Justice Act.

chunks.question: Are there any defences to assault under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Common defences include lack of intention, self-defence, consent, or act done without criminal force.

chunks.question: Does conviction under Section 351/352 affect government employment?
chunks.answer: It may affect government employment, depending on the nature and seriousness of the conviction.

chunks.question: Can a conviction under Section 351/352 IPC be appealed?
chunks.answer: Yes, convicts may appeal the decision in higher courts.

chunks.question: Is there any limitation period for trial under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, there is a limitation period which is generally 1 year for minor offences.

chunks.question: Is medical evidence required in Section 351/352 IPC cases?
chunks.answer: Medical evidence is needed if there are physical injuries due to alleged criminal force.

chunks.question: What recent trends have emerged in assault cases under IPC?
chunks.answer: Recent trends include reliance on CCTV footage, eyewitness accounts, and swift trials for summary offences.

chunks.question: Can abetment of assault under Section 351/352 IPC be punished?
chunks.answer: Yes, abetment is punishable under relevant provisions, like Section 109 IPC.

chunks.question: Is public servant immunity available under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: If the act was done in good faith while performing official duty, public servants may invoke immunity under IPC.

chunks.question: Is a complaint mandatory for starting proceedings under Section 351/352 IPC?
chunks.answer: A complaint is not mandatory; police can act on their own on receipt of information for cognizable assault offences.
